StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: Genome-wide Analysis of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: The datasets used for the analyses described in this manuscript were generated at the Institute of Cancer Genetics, Columbia University (see Fabbri et al, Analysis of the coding genome of chronic lymphocytic leukemia: Role of NOTCH1 Mutational Activation. J Exp Med, 2011) and were obtained from dbGaP at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/gap/cgi-bin/study.cgi?study_id=phs000364.v2.p1. Funding support for the study was provided by NIH grant CA37295.

GSR_Access.gsr_mode_label: Unrestricted access (institution did not respond within six months)

ConsentGroup.title: Disease-Specific (Cancer, PUB, MDS)
ConsentGroup.name: DS-CA-PUB-MDS
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: Use of the data must be related to Cancer. Requestor agrees to make results of studies using the data available to the larger scientific community. Use of the data includes methods development research (e.g., development of software or algorithms).

StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: Genome-wide Analysis of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
StudyInfo.Description: The pathogenesis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), the most common leukemia in adults, is still largely unknown since the full spectrum of genetic lesions that are present in the CLL genome, and therefore the number and identity of dysregulated cellular pathways, have not been identified. By combining next-generation sequencing and copy number analysis, we show here that the typical CLL coding genome contains less than 20 clonally represented gene alterations/case, including predominantly non-silent mutations and fewer copy number aberrations. These analyses led to the discovery of several genes not previously known to be altered in CLL. While most of these genes were affected at low frequency in an expanded CLL screening cohort, mutational activation of NOTCH1, observed in 8.3% of CLL at diagnosis, was detected at significantly higher frequency during disease progression toward Richter transformation (31.0%) as well as in chemorefractory CLL (20.8%). Consistent with the association of NOTCH1 mutations with clinically aggressive forms of the disease, NOTCH1 activation at CLL diagnosis emerged as an independent predictor of poor survival. These results provide initial data on the complexity of the CLL coding genome and identify a dysregulated pathway of diagnostic and therapeutic relevance.

ConsentGroup.title: Cancer Research and Methods
ConsentGroup.name: CRM
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: Use of the dataset is limited to scientific research relevant to the etiology, prevention, treatment and late complications of treatment of cancer, including applications proposing analytical methods, software or other research tool development. Investigators must state in the Data Access Request their intention to publish or otherwise broadly share any finding from his/her study with the scientific community.
